newsitem.title: POLAND: Raiffeisen rates Poland's KGHM offer as overpriced.
newsitem.headline: Raiffeisen rates Poland's KGHM offer as overpriced.

text.p: Poland's KGHM Polska Miedz SA copper firm's offering is overpriced at its 19.5-zloty minimum institutional price because of uncertainty over the company's cost-cutting plans, Raiffeisen Zentralbank London unit said.
Trading in 150 million KGHM shares is due to start on the Warsaw Stock Exchange on July 10.
Raiffeisen said in a report dated June 29 that its analysis focused on KGHM's ability to reduce costs, which is crucial to the firm's longer-term performance.
"Although the stock will be issued at a minimum institutional price of 19.50 zloty, we believe 15 zloty is closer to its natural long-term value," the report said.
It said that in the short term the issue should prove successful because of high investor interest in the Polish market in general and KGHM's high liquidity and its blue-chip status.
Raiffeisen said however the higher valuations presented by other analysts were based on KGHM management's forecasts of cost reductions, which it considered as too optimistic.
"KGHM is a comparatively high cost producer. An ambitious cost reduction plan forms a central plank of its future strategy. However, we believe these cost reduction plans are optimistic," it said.
Raiffeisen listed as KGHM's strengths a relatively high proportion of high margin products and by-products, its proximity to its major markets and virtually debt-free balance sheet.

Among KGHM's main weaknesses it named reserve levels possibly lower than earlier estimated, the need to move deeper with mining operations which would put costs under pressure and a strong representation of employees and the state in the shareholder structure.
